page.title: List of cultural icons of England

revision.text:
{{Culture of England}} This '''list of cultural icons of England''' is a list of people and things from any period which are independently considered to be [[cultural icon]]s characteristic of [[England]]. {{Dynamic list}}
==Animals== [[File:Suffolk Plow Team.jpg|thumb|180px|[[Suffolk Punch]] horses]] * [[Dartmoor pony]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.heart.co.uk/exeter/news/local/dartmoor-pony-under-threat/ |title=Dartmoor pony under threat |author=Wendy Buckingham |date= |work= |publisher=[[Heart (radio network)|Heart]] |accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref> * [[Exmoor pony]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.westernmorningnews.co.uk/Festival-celebrate-iconic-pony-Westcountry-moors/story-19452891-detail/story.html |title=Festival to celebrate an iconic pony of the Westcountry moors |author= |date=2 July 2013 |work= |publisher=[[Western Morning News]] |accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref> * [[Gloucester Old Spot]] pig.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theabstract.co.uk/projects/theciderpress/page9/page31/page31.html |title=Orchard open day leaves visitors as happy as a pig in muck |author= |date=2011 |work= |publisher=The Cider Press |accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref> * [[Hereford cattle]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ridgecattle.com/#!hereford/c18ip |title=Hereford Cattle |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Ridge Top Cattle |accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref> * [[New Forest Pony]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/destinations/europe/united-kingdom/england/hampshire/new-forest/articles/National-Park-focus-the-New-Forest/ |title=National Park focus: the New Forest |author=Jolyon Attwooll |date=18 April 2013 |work= |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref> * [[Black turkey|Norfolk turkey]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/news/could_norfolk_s_favourite_foods_become_protected_1_854127 |title=Could Norfolk's favourite foods become protected? |author=Stephanie Brooks |date=4 April 2011 |work= |publisher=[[Eastern Daily Press]] |accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Old English sheepdog]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-20121304 |title=Old English Sheepdog put on breed watch list |author= |date=29 October 2012 |work= |publisher=[[BBC News Online]] |accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref> * [[Suffolk Punch]] horse.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ipswichstar.co.uk/news/west_suffolk_revival_of_iconic_suffolk_punch_continues_1_3519625 |title=West Suffolk: Revival of iconic Suffolk Punch continues |author= |date=8 April 2014 |work= |publisher=[[Ipswich Star]] |accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref>
==Art== {{main|English art}} [[File:Sir Arthur Wellesley Duke of Wellington.jpg|thumb|180px|[[Thomas Lawrence (painter)|Thomas Lawrence]]'s post-[[Battle of Waterloo|Waterloo]] portrait of [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|Wellington]]]] * [[William Blake]] (1757–1827).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://arthistorynewsreport.blogspot.co.uk/2013/06/william-blakes-masterpieces-at.html |title=William Blake's Masterpieces at Metropolitan Museum |author= |date=2013 |work= |publisher=Art History News |accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> * [[John Constable]] (1776–1837);<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/10148768/Constables-The-Hay-Wain-targeted-by-Fathers4Justice-protester.html |title=Constable's ''The Hay Wain'' targeted by Fathers4Justice protester |author=Martin Evans |date=28 June 2013 |work= |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> in particular, ''[[The Hay Wain]]''.<ref name=c24>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/art362437 |title=ICONS of England – the 100 ICONS as voted by the public |publisher=[[Culture24]] |accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref> * [[George Cruikshank]] (1792–1878).<ref name="rude">{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/bbc/7821648/Rude-Britannia-Britains-history-with-the-rude-and-subversive.html |title=Rude Britannia: Britain's history with the rude and subversive |date=2010 |work= |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=5 March 2018}}</ref> * [[Thomas Gainsborough]] (1727–1788).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tate.org.uk/about/press-office/press-releases/gainsborough-0 |title=Gainsborough |author= |date=2001 |work= |publisher=[[Tate]] |accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> * [[James Gillray]] (1756/1757-1815).<ref name="rude"/> * [[Nicholas Hilliard]] (c. 1547–1619).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/10/31/telegraph-photographers-pictures-month-october/iconic-armada-portrait-elizabeth-hung-queens-house-greenwich/ |title=Telegraph photographers' pictures of the month: October |date=2017 |work= |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=5 March 2018}}</ref> * [[William Hogarth]] (1697–1764).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bristolmuseums.org.uk/bristol-museum-and-art-gallery/whats-on/william-hogarth-painter-printmaker/ |title=William Hogarth: Painter & Printmaker |author= |date=2015 |work= |publisher=[[Bristol City Museum and Art Gallery]] |accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> * Sir [[Thomas Lawrence (painter)|Thomas Lawrence]] (1769–1830).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/8071704/Thomas-Lawrence-Regency-Power-and-Brilliance-National-Portrait-Gallery.html |title=Thomas Lawrence: Regency Power and Brilliance, National Portrait Gallery |date=2010 |work= |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=5 March 2018}}</ref> * [[L. S. Lowry]] (1887–1976).<ref name=c24/> * [[Henry Moore]] (1898–1986).<ref name=c24/> * Sir [[Joshua Reynolds]] (1723–1792).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://artdaily.com/news/58252/Birmingham-Museum---Art-Gallery-acquires-iconic-Sir-Joshua-Reynolds-work |title=Birmingham Museum & Art Gallery acquires iconic Sir Joshua Reynolds work |author= |date=2013 |work= |publisher=[[ArtDaily]] |accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> * Sir [[James Thornhill]] (1675/76-1734).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp04494/sir-james-thornhill |title=Sir James Thornhill |author= |date=2018 |work= |publisher=[[National Portrait Gallery, London]] |accessdate=5 March 2018}}</ref> * [[J. M. W. Turner]] (1775–1851).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pem.org/exhibitions/163-turner_the_sea |title=Turner & the Sea |author= |date=2014 |work= |publisher=[[Peabody Essex Museum]] |accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> * [[Joseph Wright of Derby]] (1734–1797).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/ecatalogue/2011/old-master-and-british-paintings-evening-sale/lot.37.html |title=Joseph Wright of Derby, A.R.A. |author= |date=2016 |work= |publisher=[[Sotheby's]] |accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref>
==Books and documents== [[File:1612 First Quarto of King James Bible.jpg|thumb|180px|[[King James Version|King James Bible]]]] [[File:Magna Carta (British Library Cotton MS Augustus II.106) - 02.jpg|thumb|180px|[[Magna Carta]]]] * The [[King James Version|King James Bible]] (begun 1604; completed 1611).<ref name=c24/> * The [[Bill of Rights 1689]] (passed on 16 December 1689).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.parliament.uk/about/living-heritage/evolutionofparliament/parliamentaryauthority/revolution/collections1/collections-glorious-revolution/billofrights/ |title=Bill of Rights 1689 |author= |date=2016 |work= |publisher=[[Parliament of the United Kingdom]] |accessdate=1 March 2016}}</ref> * ''[[The Canterbury Tales]]'' (produced between c. 1386 and 1400) by [[Geoffrey Chaucer]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://threegoldbees.com/otherarticlea/22-chaucerpardoner/ |title=A Portrait of the Pardoner from Chaucer's ''Canterbury Tales'' |author= |date=2016 |work= |publisher=Three Gold Bees |accessdate=1 March 2016}}</ref> * The [[Domesday Book]] (completed 1086).<ref name=c24/> * [[William Shakespeare]]'s [[First Folio]] (published posthumously in 1623).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bl.uk/press-releases/2015/september/british-literary-icons-to-be-exhibited-in-china-for-the-first-time |title=British literary icons to be exhibited in China for the first time |author= |date=2015 |work= |publisher=[[British Library]] |accessdate=1 March 2016}}</ref> * The [[Lindisfarne Gospels]] (produced c. 700 A.D.), attributed to [[Eadfrith of Lindisfarne]].<ref name=c24/> * ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' (begun 1937; completed 1949), by [[J. R. R. Tolkien]].<ref name=c24/> * [[Magna Carta]] (agreed by [[John, King of England|King John]] on 15 June 1215).<ref name=c24/> * ''[[Mrs Beeton's Book of Household Management]]'' (1861), edited by [[Isabella Beeton]].<ref name=c24/> * The [[Charles Dickens bibliography|novels]] of [[Charles Dickens]] (1812–1870).<ref name=c24/> * ''[[On the Origin of Species]]'' (1859) by [[Charles Darwin]].<ref name=c24/> * ''[[Our Island Story]]'' (1905) by [[Henrietta Elizabeth Marshall|H. E. Marshall]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2014/feb/07/our-island-story-conservative-david-cameron |title=''Our Island Story'': Not as Conservative as David Cameron imagines |author=Tom Holland |date=2014 |work= |publisher=[[theguardian.com|The Guardian Online]] |accessdate=1 March 2016}}</ref> * The ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' (begun 1857; first edition completed 1928).<ref name=c24/> * ''[[Pride and Prejudice]]'' (1813) by [[Jane Austen]].<ref name=c24/> * The works of [[Beatrix Potter]] (1866–1943).<ref name=c24/>
==Buildings and structures== [[File:Big Ben - geograph.org.uk - 1629575.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Big Ben]], a.k.a. the ''Elizabeth Tower'']] [[File:Home to criminals, princes and ravens - geograph.org.uk - 1600286.jpg|thumb|The [[Tower of London]]]] * The [[Abbey Road, London|Abbey Road]] [[zebra crossing]], famous for its association with [[the Beatles]]' 1969 album ''[[Abbey Road]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/iconic-abbey-road-crossing-made-271019 |title=Iconic Abbey Road crossing made famous by The Beatles awarded listed status |author= |date=2010 |work= |publisher=[[BBC News Online]] |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> * The [[Angel of the North]], contemporary sculpture by Sir [[Antony Gormley]], located near [[Gateshead]] in [[Tyne and Wear]] (completed 1998).<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/artblog/2008/feb/13/happybirthdayangeloftheno Guardian: Angel of the North]. Retrieved 15 December 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.gateshead.gov.uk/Council%20and%20Democracy/news/News%20Articles/Angel%20of%20the%20North%20an%20English%20icon.aspx Gateshead Council: Angel of the North an English Icon]. Retrieved 15 December 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.futurematters.org.uk/drivers/culturalregeneration.asp Future Matters: Cultural Regeneration]. Retrieved 15 December 2012. "The development of cultural icons such as Sage, Baltic and The Angel of the North have shown that iconic projects can go a long way to improving external perceptions of an area, as well as providing environmental, economic and social benefits."</ref> * [[Big Ben]] (the nickname for the bell; the clock tower of the [[Houses of Parliament]] was renamed the ''Elizabeth Tower'' in 2012).<ref>{{cite book | title=An Unstoppable Force: Daring to Become the Church God Had in Mind | publisher=Flagship Church Resources | author=McManus, Erwin Raphael | year=2001 | pages=113}}</ref> * [[Blackpool Tower]] (opened 14 May 1894).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-lancashire-14743747 |title=Blackpool Tower reopens to public after £20m restoration |author= |date=2011 |work= |publisher=[[BBC News Online]] |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> * [[Buckingham Palace]], London residence of the British monarch since 1837.<ref name="royal.uk">{{cite web|url=https://www.royal.uk/royal-residences-buckingham-palace|title=Buckingham Palace|author=Royal Household|website=Royal Family website|accessdate=21 April 2016}}</ref> * [[Canterbury Cathedral]] (founded 597; completely rebuilt 1070–1077; east end enlarged early 12th century, and largely rebuilt in [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] style following a fire in 1174).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://eastkentfreemasons.org/canterbury-cathedral-appeal/ |title=PGM Launches Canterbury Cathedral Appeal |author= |date=2015 |work= |publisher=[[Kent Museum of Freemasonry|East Kent Freemasons]] |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> * [[Durham Cathedral]], formally ''the Cathedral Church of Christ, Blessed Mary the Virgin and St Cuthbert of Durham'' (present cathedral founded 1093).<ref name=c24a>{{cite web |url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/history-and-heritage/art38995 |title=New List Of 20 More English Cultural Icons Announced |author= |date=2006 |work= |publisher=[[Culture24]] |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> * [[EMI]]'s [[The Old Vinyl Factory|Old Vinyl Factory]] in [[Hayes, Hillingdon|Hayes, Middlesex]], where records by [[The Beatles]] and other EMI artists were manufactured in the 1960s and after.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/news/local-news/one-off-gigs-iconic-old-vinyl-5974659 |title=One-off gigs at iconic Old Vinyl Factory |author=Jack Griffith |date=2012 |work= |publisher=GetWestLondon |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> * [[Globe Theatre]] (the modern reconstruction, named "[[Shakespeare's Globe]]", opened in 1997 approximately 750 feet [230 m] from the site of the original[s]; the second Globe was pulled down 1644–45).<ref name=c24/> * [[Hadrian's Wall]] (begun in 122 A.D.).<ref name=c24/> * [[The Iron Bridge]], across the [[River Severn]] in [[Shropshire]] (opened 1781).<ref name=c24/> * The [[National Memorial Arboretum]], described by [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Prince William]] in 2011 as an "iconic focal point" for the nation's remembrance of fallen soldiers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/prince-william/8883203/Prince-William-National-Memorial-Arboretum-an-iconic-focal-point.html |title=Prince William: National Memorial Arboretum 'an iconic focal point' |publisher= |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Pier#Pleasure piers|Seaside pier]]s (first built early 19th century).<ref name=c24/> * The [[Shaftesbury Memorial Fountain]], commemorating [[Anthony Ashley-Cooper, 7th Earl of Shaftesbury|Lord Shaftesbury]]; the statue of [[Anteros]] is named ''The Angel of Christian Charity''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/survey-london/vols31-2/pt2/pp101-110 |title=The Shaftesbury Memorial Fountain |publisher=[[British History Online]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Spaghetti junction]], or [[Gravelly Hill Interchange]]; opened 24 May 1972.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/work-restarts-to-protect-one-of-britains-most-iconic-road-structures |title=Work restarts to protect one of Britain's most iconic road structures |publisher=[[Gov.uk]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Stonehenge]], a [[prehistoric]] ring of [[standing stones]] in [[Wiltshire]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/visit/places/stonehenge/history/ | title = History of Stonehenge | publisher = [[English Heritage]] | access-date = 2016-06-07 }}</ref> * [[Tower of London]], officially ''Her Majesty's Royal Palace and Fortress of the Tower of London'' (the [[White Tower (Tower of London)|White Tower]] built 1078; expanded in the 12th & 13th centuries).<ref name=c24/> * [[Westminster Abbey]], formally ''the Collegiate Church of St Peter at Westminster'' (construction of the present church began 1245).<ref name=c24/> * [[York Minster]], formally ''the Cathedral and Metropolitical Church of Saint Peter in York'' (long history; the cathedral was declared complete and [[Consecration|consecrated]] 1472).<ref name=c24/>
==Clothing== [[File:Henry M Stanley 1872.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Henry Morton Stanley]] wearing a [[pith helmet]]]] * [[Blazer]], originated with the red 'blazers' of the [[Lady Margaret Boat Club]] (1825), the rowing club of [[St. John's College, Cambridge]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/men/fashion-and-style/10940463/Blazing-a-trail-the-origins-of-the-mens-blazer.html |title=Blazing a trail: the origins of the men's blazer |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Bowler hat]], created 1849 for soldier and politician [[Edward Coke (1824–89)|Edward Coke]].<ref name=c24a/> * [[Deerstalker]] hat, popularly associated with representations of fictional private investigator [[Sherlock Holmes]]. * R. Griggs's [[Dr. Martens]] AirWair boot; associated with, among others, [[skinhead]]s and [[Punk subculture|punk]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://therake.com/stories/style/how-dr-martens-became-iconic/ |title=How Dr. Martens Became Iconic |date= |work= |publisher=The Rake |accessdate=5 March 2018}}</ref> * The tailless [[Tuxedo|dinner jacket]] suit, the earliest recorded example of which was ordered by the [[Prince of Wales]] (later [[Edward VII]]) from [[Savile Row]] tailors [[Henry Poole & Co]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.maxim.com/style/james-bond-007-style-2015-10 |title=7 iconic James Bond styles |author= |date=2015 |work= |publisher=[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]] |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> * [[Flat cap]], dating back to the 14th century in [[Northern England]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/news/local/localbrad/12879927.Flat_caps_donned_to_raise_vital_funds/ |title=Flat caps donned to raise vital funds |author= |date=2015 |work= |publisher=[[Telegraph & Argus]] |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> * [[Frock coat]], popularised by [[Albert, Prince Consort|Prince Albert]], consort to [[Queen Victoria]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O13952/frock-coat-unknown/ |title=Frock coat |publisher=[[Victoria and Albert Museum]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Miniskirt]], so-called since the 1960s, when it became associated with "[[Swinging London]]."<ref name=c24/> * [[Pith helmet]], popular from the 1870s with military personnel in the [[Tropics]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.militarytrader.com/military-trader-news/pith_helmets_of_the_british_empire |title=Pith Helmets of the British Empire |author= |date=2008 |work= |publisher=Military Trader |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> * [[Ruff (clothing)|Ruff]], formal neck-wear from the mid-sixteenth century to the mid-seventeenth century, following [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth I]]'s New Year's gift to her ladies in 1565.<ref>Mary S. Lovell, ''Bess of Hardwick, Empire Builder'' 2005: 184.</ref> * [[Ben Sherman]] clothing brand; typically associated with [[Mod (subculture)|mod]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fashionreview.co.uk/ben-sherman-fashion/ |title=Ben Sherman – Iconic British Fashion |date=2018 |work= |publisher=London Fashion Review |accessdate=5 March 2018}}</ref> * [[Smock-frock]], dating back to the early 18th century in [[the Midlands]] and [[Southern England]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://katedaviesdesigns.com/2011/06/24/smocks-galore/ |title=Smocks Galore! |author= |date=2011 |work= |publisher=Kate Davies Designs |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> * [[Top hat]], said to have caused a riot when [[John Hetherington]] first wore one in public on 15 January 1797.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://houseappeal.wordpress.com/2012/12/28/enduring-high-style-the-iconic-top-hat/ |title=Enduring high style: the iconic top hat |author= |date=2012 |work= |publisher=House Appeal |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> * [[Trench coat]], the invention of which is claimed by both [[Burberry]] and [[Aquascutum]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.retrochick.co.uk/iconic-styles-the-trench-coat/ |title=Iconic styles: the trench coat |author= |date=2012 |work= |publisher=Retrochick |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref>
==Customs and traditions== [[File:CheeseRollingRace.jpg|thumb|[[Cooper's Hill Cheese-Rolling and Wake]]]] * [[Aunt Sally]], traditional English [[Pub game|game]] in which players throw sticks or battens at a model of an old woman's head, usually played in pub gardens and fairgrounds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britishpathe.com/video/aunt-sally |title=Aunt Sally |publisher=[[Pathé News|British Pathé]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Beating the bounds]], ancient custom still observed in some English [[parish]]es; members of a community walk the boundaries of the parish, usually led by church officials, to share the knowledge of where they lay, and to pray for protection and blessings for the lands.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britishpathe.com/video/beating-the-bounds-of-london |title=Beating the Bounds of London |publisher=[[Pathé News|British Pathé]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Birdman Rally]], flying; format originated in [[Selsey]], [[West Sussex]], 1971.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/sussex/7387341.stm |title=Council gives £15,000 for Birdman |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Britannia Coco-nut Dancers]], a troupe of [[Lancashire|Lancastrian]] [[clog dancer]]s who perform every Easter in [[Bacup]], dancing 7 miles (11 km) across the town.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/law-and-order/10459159/Morris-dancing-troop-Britannia-Coconutters-banned-from-hometown-over-safety-concerns.html |title=Morris dancing troop Britannia Coconutters banned from hometown over safety concerns |author= |date=2013 |work= |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=19 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Coconut shy]], traditional [[funfair]] and [[fête]] game consisting of throwing wooden balls at a row of coconuts balanced on posts; may have originated at the annual Pleasure Fair in [[Kingston, Surrey]], 1867; probably derives from the game of [[Aunt Sally]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/personal-view/3577301/Of-coconuts-and-cabbages-champagne-and-the-Queen.html |title=Of coconuts and cabbages, champagne and the Queen |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Cooper's Hill Cheese-Rolling and Wake]], annual event held on the Spring [[Bank Holiday]] at [[Brockworth]], near [[Gloucester]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-gloucestershire-22681708 |title=Gloucestershire cheese-rolling takes place despite warning |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Cotswold Olimpick Games]], probably began 1622.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/shortcuts/2012/may/31/british-olympic-cotswold-olympicks |title=For the real British Olympic spirit, visit the Cotswold Olimpicks |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Gurn]]ing, rural English tradition of assuming a distorted [[facial expression]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/sep/22/the-northerner-round-up-gurning |title=The man with the golden gurn |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[International Birdman]], flying competitions held in [[Bognor Regis]] and [[Worthing]], [[West Sussex]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-28263178 |title=Worthing International Birdman: One man's quest to win |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[London Marathon]], first run 29 March 1981.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/men/active/10-things-no-one-tells-you-before-you-run-the-london-marathon/ |title=10 things no one tells you before you run the London Marathon |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Maypole]] dancing, found historically in England and in areas of Wales and Scotland under English influence.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/earth/countryside/10925617/Yorkshire-town-in-uproar-over-ancient-maypole-tree-cut-down-without-warning.html |title=Yorkshire town in uproar over ancient maypole tree cut down without warning |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref>
[[File:Cotswold Morris handkerchiefs 20040501.jpg|thumb|[[Cotswolds|Cotswold]] [[morris dance]]]] * [[Morris dance|Morris dancing]], earliest known and surviving English written mention dated to 1448.<ref name=c24/> * [[Nottingham Goose Fair]], dates back more than 700 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britishpathe.com/video/the-goose-fair |title=The Goose Fair 1935 |publisher=[[Pathé News|British Pathé]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Royal Maundy]]; small silver coins known as "Maundy money" ceremonially distributed as symbolic [[alms]] to elderly recipients by the [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|Monarch]] or a royal official at a religious service in the [[Church of England]], held on [[Maundy Thursday]], the day before [[Good Friday]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/queen-elizabeth-II/12203636/Queen-hands-out-90th-birthday-coins-at-Royal-Maundy-service.html |title=Queen hands out 90th birthday coins at Royal Maundy service |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Royal Shrovetide Football]], played annually in [[Ashbourne, Derbyshire]] since c. 1667.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/earth/countryside/4696484/Shrove-Tuesday-anyone-for-football.html |title=Shrove Tuesday: anyone for football? |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Shin-kicking]]: a [[combat sport]] that originated in England in the early 17th century; it involves two contestants attempting to kick each other on the shin to force their opponent to the ground.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/gloucestershire/content/articles/2009/04/22/cotswold_olimpicks_feature.shtml |title=Cotswold Olimpicks |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Well dressing]], summer [[Tradition|custom]] practised in rural England in which [[Water well|well]]s, [[Spring (hydrosphere)|spring]]s or other water sources are decorated with designs created from [[flower]] [[petal]]s; most closely associated with the [[Peak District]] of [[Derbyshire]] and [[Staffordshire]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-derbyshire-36215998 |title=Crowds flock to Tissington Well Dressings |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Wellie wanging]], game originating from [[Upperthong]], [[Holmfirth]]; competitors are required to hurl a [[Wellington boot]] as far as possible within boundary lines.
==Education== [[File:Harrow School - geograph.org.uk - 76988.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Harrow School]]]] * [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge University]], founded in 1209. * [[Charterhouse School]], founded by [[Thomas Sutton]] in 1611.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/domesday/dblock/GB-496000-144000/page/11 |title=1986: Charterhouse School |publisher=[[BBC Domesday Reloaded]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Eton College]], founded in 1440.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2006/jun/11/historybooks.features2 |title=Old-school tie |author=Olivia Laing |date=2006 |work= |publisher=[[The Observer]] |accessdate=19 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Grammar school]]s: selective tier of England's [[Tripartite System]] of state-funded secondary education between 1945 and the 1970s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hitchensblog.mailonsunday.co.uk/grammar-schools/ |title=Grammar wreckers KNEW they would make our schools worse |publisher=[[Mail Online]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Harrow School]], founded in 1572. * [[University of Oxford|Oxford University]], evidence of teaching since 1096.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/nov/15/oxford-university-architecture-dreaming-spires-hard-cash |title=Oxford's dreaming spires... and hard cash |author=Rowan Moore |date=2015 |work=[[The Observer]] |accessdate=19 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Roedean School]], founded in 1885.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/educationnews/8844431/Half-of-girls-at-Roedean-School-now-come-from-abroad.html |title=Half of girls at Roedean School now come from abroad |author=Andrew Hough |date=2011 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=19 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Rugby School]], founded in 1567. * [[Winchester College]], established by [[William of Wykeham]] in 1382.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2000/aug/26/education.schools |title=Winchester tops public school A-level league |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref>
==Emblems== [[File:Wappen Kaltbrunn.png|thumb|160px|[[Saint George]]]] * [[John Bull]], a [[national personification]] of the United Kingdom in general and England in particular, especially in [[Editorial cartoon|political cartoon]]s and similar graphic works; created by Dr [[John Arbuthnot]] and [[Alexander Pope]] in 1712.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historic-uk.com/CultureUK/John-Bull/ |title=John Bull |publisher=''Historic UK'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Quercus robur|English Oak]], consequent upon the future [[Charles II of England|King Charles II]] hiding from his [[Roundhead|Parliamentarian]] pursuers in the oak tree at [[Boscobel House]], in 1650 during the [[English Civil War]].<ref name=c24/> * [[Flag of England|Flag of St George]], dating from the [[Middle Ages]]; used as a component in the design of the [[Union Flag]] in 1606.<ref name=c24/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/news/latest-news/452525/Fury-cops-ignore-ISIS-Hezbollah-flags-but-ban-St-George-s-flags |title=St George's flag banned |author=Ed Riley |date=2015 |work= |publisher=[[Daily Star (British newspaper)|Daily Star]] |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> * The [[Lion]]/[[Lion (heraldry)|Lion passant]]; evidence of a seal bearing two lions passant used by the future [[John, King of England|King John]] during the lifetime of his father, [[Henry II of England|Henry II]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/notesandqueries/query/0,5753,-17023,00.html |title=Notes and Queries |author= |date=2011 |work= |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Remembrance poppy]], used since 1921 to commemorate military personnel who have died in war; distributed by [[The Royal British Legion]] in the weeks leading up to [[Remembrance Sunday]], in support of current and former British military personnel.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/history/world-war-one/11169839/My-poppy-my-soldier-a-service-to-Queen-and-country.html |title=My poppy, my soldier: a service to Queen and country |author=Ann Mullard |date=2014 |work= |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> * The [[Rose (symbolism)#England|Rose]] is the [[National symbols of England|national flower of England]], a usage dating back to the [[English civil war]]s of the 15th century.<ref name=c24/> * [[Saint George]], patron saint of England by the 14th century.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/technology-science/st-georges-day-google-creates-5566431 |title=St. George's Day: Google creates doodle to celebrate England's patron saint |author=Ann Stenhouse |date=2015 |work= |publisher=[[Daily Mirror]] |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref>
==Festivals== [[File:Kate Greenaway - May day.jpg|thumb|[[May day]] illustration by [[Kate Greenaway]] (1846–1901)]] * [[Commonwealth Day]]: annual celebration of the [[Commonwealth of Nations]] held on the second Monday in March. * [[Saint George's Day]]: 23 April, the traditionally accepted date of [[Saint George]]'s death in 303 AD.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2016/03/22/when-is-st-georges-day-and-what-do-we-know-about-englands-patron/ |title=When is St George's Day? |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[May Day]]: usually celebrated on 1 May.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrylife.co.uk/country-life/6-of-the-best-may-day-festivals-71613 |title=6 of the best May Day festivals |publisher=''[[Country Life (magazine)|Country Life]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Commonwealth Day|Empire Day]] (1904–1958): last school day before 24 May, [[Queen Victoria]]'s birthday.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/archive/princesselizabeth/6602.shtml |title=Empire Day, 1946: Speech by HRH Princess Elizabeth |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Whitsun]]: the festival of [[Pentecost]], the seventh Sunday after [[Easter]], which commemorates the descent of the [[Holy Spirit]] upon [[Jesus|Christ]]'s [[Disciple (Christianity)|disciple]]s (''[[Acts of the Apostles]]'', Chapter 2).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hitchensblog.mailonsunday.co.uk/2014/06/a-whitsun-address.html |title=A Whitsun Address |publisher=[[Mail Online]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Trafalgar Day]]: 21 October, celebration of [[Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson|Nelson]]'s victory over the combined [[First French Empire|French]] and [[Enlightenment in Spain|Spanish]] fleets at the [[Battle of Trafalgar]] on 21 October 1805.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/business/tourism/campaign_for_trafalgar_day_gains_momentum_when_would_you_like_the_may_day_bank_holiday_moved_to_1_819406 |title=Campaign for Trafalgar Day gains momentum |publisher=''[[Eastern Daily Press]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Boxing Day]]: 26 (or 27 when 26 is a Sunday) December.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyextra.com/feature/brief-history-boxing-day |title=A brief history of Boxing Day |publisher=''[[BBC History]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Glastonbury Festival]]: performing arts festival that takes place near [[Pilton, Somerset]]; inaugurated in 1970.<ref name=c24/>
==Fictional characters== [[File:Basil Rathbone Sherlock Holmes.jpeg|thumb|160px|[[Sherlock Holmes]] (played by [[Basil Rathbone]])]] * [[Biggles]], nickname of pilot and adventurer James Bigglesworth, created in 1932 by [[W. E. Johns|Captain W. E. Johns]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/insideout/east/series9/week_three.shtml |title=Biggles' plane |author= |date=2016 |work= |publisher=[[Inside Out (2002 TV programme)|BBC Inside Out]] |accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref> * [[James Bond]], [[Secret Intelligence Service|British Secret Service]] agent created in 1953 by [[Ian Fleming]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.statepress.com/article/2015/11/best-bond-actors-spectre-connery-craig |title=Ranking the best 'Bond' actors from No. 1 to 007 |author=Obie Dieke |date=2015 |work= |publisher=[[The State Press]] |accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Dixon of Dock Green]], typical "bobby" on the [[Beat (police)|beat]], first appeared in ''[[The Blue Lamp]]'' (1949).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/how-committing-fighting-writing-crime-8156127 |title=How committing, fighting and writing about crime has been changed by modern technology |author=Simon Kernick |date=2016 |work= |publisher=[[Daily Mirror]] |accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Falstaff]], fat, boastful knight who appears in three plays by [[William Shakespeare]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b05ssng2 |title=Book of the Week |author= |date=2015 |work= |publisher=[[BBC Radio 4]] |accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Alf Garnett]], [[East End of London|East End]] [[patriarch]] first seen in [[sitcom]] ''[[Till Death Us Do Part]]'', created in 1965 by [[Johnny Speight]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.express.co.uk/showbiz/tv-radio/656417/Simon-Day-Alf-Garnett-Till-Death-Do-Us-Part-remake |title=The Fast Show's Simon Day to star as Alf Garnett in Till Death Do Us Part remake |author=Neela Debnath |date=2016 |work= |publisher=[[Daily Express]] |accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Sherlock Holmes]], [[Private investigator|private detective]] created in 1887 by [[Arthur Conan Doyle|Sir Arthur Conan Doyle]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-27487080 |title=Sherlock Holmes: Can a fictional man be a London icon? |author=Beth Rose |date=2014 |work= |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Robin Hood]], [[hero]]ic [[outlaw]] of [[English folklore]], dating from the 13th century.<ref name=c24/> * [[Lord Snooty]], [[comic strip]] character created in 1938 and drawn mostly by [[Dudley D. Watkins]]. * [[Noddy (character)|Noddy]], little wooden puppet created in 1949 by [[Enid Blyton]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/classic-media-noddy-rights-chorion-297387 |title=U.S. Group Classic Media Grabs Rights to Iconic British Creation Noddy From Chorion |author=Stuart Kemp |date=2012 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Paddington Bear]], created by [[Michael Bond]] (b. 1926) in 1958.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://time.com/3667559/paddington-bear-trivia/ |title=9 Things Everyone Should Know About Paddington Bear |author=Joseph C. Lin |date=2015 |work= |publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Harry Potter]], created by [[J. K. Rowling]] in 1997.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2015-07-31/happy-birthday-harry-potter-the-chosen-one-turns-35-today |title=Happy birthday, Harry Potter! The Chosen One turns 35 today |author=Sarah Doran |date=2015 |work= |publisher=[[Radio Times]] |accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Rupert Bear]], [[comic strip]] bear created in 1920 by [[Mary Tourtel]] and popularised from 1935 by [[Alfred Bestall]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/history-and-heritage/art16096 |title=Children's Museum Opens In Canterbury – Home of Rupert Bear |author= |date=2003 |work= |publisher=[[Culture24]] |accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Sooty]], bear created by [[Harry Corbett]] in 1948.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.licensing.biz/big-interviews/read/richard-cadell-on-saving-sooty-brand-longevity-and-stage-shows/039309 |title=Richard Cadell on saving Sooty, brand longevity and stage shows |author= |date=2014 |work= |publisher=[[Licensing.biz]] |accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Winnie-the-Pooh]], created by [[A. A. Milne]] in 1926.<ref name=c24/> * [[Thomas the Tank Engine]] created by [[Wilbert Awdry]] in 1942.

==Folk tales== [[File:History of Sir Richard Whittington(1770)-00-inset-detail.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Richard Whittington|Dick Whittington]]]] * [[Dick Whittington and His Cat]]: English [[folklore]] surrounding the real-life [[Richard Whittington]] (c. 1354–1423); earliest written form: 1604-5.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/legacies/myths_legends/england/london/article_1.shtml |title=Oh yes he was! Oh no he wasn't! |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Goldilocks and the Three Bears]]: first recorded in narrative form by [[Robert Southey]], 1837.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goodreads.com/author/show/107344.Robert_Southey |title=Robert Southey (Author of Goldilocks and the Three Bears) |publisher=[[Goodreads]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Humpty Dumpty]]: English [[nursery rhyme]]; character typically portrayed as an [[Anthropomorphism|anthropomorphic]] [[Egg (food)|egg]], though not explicitly described so; first recorded versions date from the late 18th century. * [[Jack and the Beanstalk]]: "The Story of Jack Spriggins and the Enchanted Bean" appeared in 1734; "The History of Jack and the Bean-Stalk" published by Benjamin Tabart in 1807.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theplayhouse.org.uk/bagofbeans/category/drama-and-story-ideas/versions-of-the-story/ |title=Versions and history of Jack and the Beanstalk |publisher=The Play House |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Jack the Giant Killer]]: "The History of Jack and the Giants" was published by J. White of [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]] in 1711.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2012/nov/23/jack-the-giant-slayer-killer |title=Jack the Giant Slayer: big news or the height of nonsense? |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[The Three Little Pigs]]: first appeared in ''The Nursery Rhymes of England'' by [[James Orchard Halliwell-Phillipps]] in c. 1886.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/gini-graham-scott/the-three-little-pigs-and_b_9394494.html |title=The Three Little Pigs and the Big Bad Trump |publisher=''[[The Huffington Post]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Tom Thumb]]: the tale of Tom Thumb is the first English [[fairy tale]]; the earliest surviving text (presumed to be by [[Richard Johnson (16th century)|Richard Johnson]]) was printed in London in 1621.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/TomThumb |title=Literature / Tom Thumb |publisher=[[TV Tropes]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref>

==Orders, decorations, and medals== [[File:Order of the British Empire Officer.jpg|thumb|90px|[[Order of the British Empire]]]] {{main|Orders, decorations, and medals of the United Kingdom}} * [[British Empire Medal]], awarded for meritorious civil or military service worthy of recognition by the [[British monarchy|Crown]]. * [[Distinguished Service Order]] (DSO), military decoration awarded for meritorious or distinguished service by officers of the armed forces during wartime, typically in actual combat.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/history/11485980/Our-heroic-airmen-must-not-be-forgotten.html |title=Our heroic airmen must not be forgotten |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[George Cross]], highest gallantry award for civilians, as well as for members of the armed forces in actions for which purely military honours would not normally be granted.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/1999/nov/23/northernireland.simonjeffery |title=George Cross: a history |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Order of the British Empire]], includes ''OBE'' (Officer of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire) and ''MBE'' (Member of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire); rewards contributions to the arts and sciences, work with charitable and welfare organisations, and public service outside [[Her Majesty's Civil Service]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11990088 |title=Guide to the Honours |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Victoria Cross]], highest [[military decoration]], awarded for [[Courage|valour]] "in the [[Combat|face of the enemy]]" to members of the armed forces of various [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] countries, and former [[British Empire]] territories.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/10483959/The-Victoria-Cross-and-the-George-Cross-The-Complete-History-review.html |title=The Victoria Cross and the George Cross: The Complete History, review |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref>
==Periodicals== [[File:The Times - July 6, 1863.jpg|thumb|''[[The Times]]'', 6 July 1863]] * ''[[Country Life (magazine)|Country Life]]'', launched by [[Edward Hudson (magazine owner)|Edward Hudson]] in 1897.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/jan/09/pressandpublishing.uknews |title=Country Life marks 110th birthday |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Daily Mail]]'', first published by [[Alfred Harmsworth, 1st Viscount Northcliffe|Lord Northcliffe]] in 1896.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Daily-Mail |title=Daily Mail |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * The ''[[Eagle (British comics)|Eagle]]'', seminal [[British comics|comic]] published 1950–1969.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/11309218/Nothing-funny-about-adults-reading-comic.html |title=Nothing funny about adults reading comics |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * The ''[[Financial Times]]'', founded by James Sheridan and [[Horatio Bottomley]] in 1888.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Financial-Times |title=Financial Times |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * ''[[The Gentleman's Magazine]]'', founded by [[Edward Cave]] in 1731.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/The-Gentlemans-Magazine |title=The Gentleman's Magazine: English periodical |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * ''[[The Lancet]]'', weekly [[peer-review]]ed [[general medical journal]] founded by [[Thomas Wakley]] in 1823.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/The-Lancet |title=The Lancet: British medical journal |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Pall Mall Gazette]]'', evening newspaper founded by [[George Murray Smith]] in 1865.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://spartacus-educational.com/Jpall.htm |title=Pall Mall Gazette |publisher=[[Spartacus Educational]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society]]'', [[scientific journal]] published by the [[Royal Society]]; established in 1665.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/grrlscientist/2015/mar/06/royal-society-celebrates-350-years-of-scientific-publishing |title=Royal Society celebrates 350 years of scientific publishing |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Private Eye]]'', fortnightly [[Satire|satirical]] and [[Current affairs (news format)|current affairs]] magazine launched in 1961.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Magazine/PrivateEye?from=Main.PrivateEye |title=Magazine / Private Eye |publisher=[[TV Tropes]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Punch (magazine)|Punch]]'', weekly magazine of [[humour]] and [[satire]] established by [[Henry Mayhew]] and engraver [[Ebenezer Landells]] in 1841.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Punch-British-periodical |title=Punch: British periodical |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * ''[[The Times]]'', daily national newspaper based in London; began in 1785 under the title ''The Daily Universal Register''; became ''The Times'' on 1 January 1788.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/The-Times |title=The Times: British newspaper |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Tit-Bits]]'' (a.k.a. ''Tit-Bits from all the interesting Books, Periodicals, and Newspapers of the World''), weekly magazine founded by [[George Newnes]] in 1881.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/press/stop-press-old-news-is-good-news-antique-newspapers-1225196.html |title=Stop press – old news is good news: Antique newspapers |publisher=''[[The Independent]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Viz (comics)|Viz]]'', adult [[Humor magazine|comic magazine]] founded in 1979 by [[Chris Donald]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/4793739/Bleak-vision-great-gags.html |title=Bleak vision, great gags |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref>
==Philosophers== [[File:John-Locke-660x350-1412917543.jpg|thumb|180px|[[John Locke]], by [[Godfrey Kneller|Kneller]]]] * [[Jeremy Bentham]] (1748–1832), founder of modern [[utilitarianism]]: that "it is the greatest happiness of the greatest number that is the measure of right and wrong".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ucl.ac.uk/museums/jeremy-bentham |title=Jeremy Bentham auto-icon |publisher=[[University College London]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Thomas Hobbes]] (1588–1679), wrote ''[[Leviathan (Hobbes book)|Leviathan]]'' (1651), the foundation of most later Western [[political philosophy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/hobbes-moral/ |title=Hobbes's Moral and Political Philosophy |publisher=[[Stanford University]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * [[John Locke]] (1632–1704), influential [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] thinker, commonly known as the "Father of [[Liberalism]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historytoday.com/mark-goldie/john-locke-icon-liberty |title=John Locke: Icon of Liberty |publisher=''[[History Today]]'' |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * [[John Stuart Mill]] (1806–1873), influential [[Liberalism|liberal]] thinker, wrote on [[social theory]], [[Political philosophy|political theory]] and [[political economy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/history/inourtime/greatest_philosopher_js_mill.shtml |title=John Stuart Mill (1806–1873) |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Bertrand Russell]] (1872–1970), [[logic]]ian, [[Mathematics|mathematician]], and [[Activism|political activist]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/belief/2013/nov/18/bertrand-russell-philosopher-religion-ethics-life |title=Bertrand Russell: philosopher, mathematician and optimist |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref>

==Religion== [[File:A03 ADRIANO IV.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Pope Adrian IV]] / Nicholas Breakspear: the only English [[Pope]]]] [[File:SmrtBecketta.jpg|thumb|[[Martyr]]dom of [[Thomas Becket]]]]
{{main|Religion in England}} * [[Pope Adrian IV]] (Nicholas Breakspear, c.?1100 – 1159); the only English [[Pope]], 1154–1159.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-beds-bucks-herts-21656680 |title=Nicholas Breakspear: The only English Pope |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Saint Alban]] (died c. 209–305 A.D.); first recorded British Christian martyr.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Saint-Alban |title=Saint Alban: British martyr |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Anselm of Canterbury]] (c. 1033 – 1109); Archbishop of Canterbury, 1093–1109.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Saint-Anselm-of-Canterbury |title=Saint Anselm of Canterbury: Archbishop and philosopher |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], senior [[bishop]] and principal leader of the [[Church of England]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/archbishop-of-Canterbury |title=Archbishop of Canterbury |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Augustine of Canterbury]] (6th century), first Archbishop of Canterbury in 597 A.D.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Saint-Augustine-of-Canterbury |title=Saint Augustine of Canterbury |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Thomas Becket]] (c. 1120–1170), Archbishop of Canterbury from 1162 until his murder in 1170; [[Veneration|venerated]] as [[saint]] and [[martyr]] by both [[Catholic Church]] and [[Anglican Communion]]; engaged in conflict with [[Henry II of England|Henry II]] over rights and privileges of the Church and was murdered by followers of the king in [[Canterbury Cathedral]]; [[Canonization|canonised]] soon after by [[Pope Alexander III]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/becket_thomas.shtml |title=Thomas Becket (c. 1120 – 1170) |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref> * The [[Bede|Venerable Bede]] (672/673-735); his ''[[Historia ecclesiastica gentis Anglorum]]'' earned him the title "The Father of [[History of England|English History]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/bede_st.shtml |title=The Venerable Bede (673 AD – 735 AD) |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Church of England]], from 6th to 16th century in [[full communion]] with the [[Holy See|See of Rome]]; the [[English Reformation]] saw a break from the authority of the [[Pope]] and the [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic Church]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/christianity/cofe/cofe_1.shtml |title=Church of England |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Fidei defensor]]'' or "Defender of the Faith", a subsidiary title of English and later British monarchs since granted in 1521 by [[Pope Leo X]] to King [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/defender-of-the-faith |title=Defender of the faith: English royal title |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Julian of Norwich]] (c. 1342 – c. 1416), English [[Anchorite|anchoress]] and important Christian [[Mysticism|mystic]] and theologian.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Julian-of-Norwich |title=Julian of Norwich: English mystic |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Thomas More]] (1478–1535), [[Veneration|venerated]] by [[Catholic Church|Catholic]]s as Saint Thomas More ([[Canonization|canonised]] 1535); author of ''[[Utopia (book)|Utopia]]'' (1516); his story is told in ''[[A Man for All Seasons (1966 film)|A Man for All Seasons]]'' (1966).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/more_sir_thomas.shtml |title=Thomas More (1478–1535) |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref> * [[John Henry Newman|Cardinal Newman]] (1801–1890), [[Beatification|beatified]] in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/today/hi/today/newsid_8720000/8720596.stm |title=Cardinal Newman |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref> * [[English post-Reformation oaths|Post-Reformation oaths]]: English churchmen and others were required to assent to religious changes starting in the 16th century and continuing for more than 250 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/11177a.htm |title=English Post-Reformation Oaths |publisher=New Advent website |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Roman Catholic Relief Act 1829]], culmination of the process of [[Catholic Emancipation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/christianity/catholic/catholic_1.shtml |title=Roman Catholic Church |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref> * The [[Salvation Army]], founded by [[Catherine Booth|Catherine]] and [[William Booth]], 1865.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/christianity/subdivisions/salvationarmy_1.shtml |title=Salvation Army |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref> * [[John Wesley]] (1703–1791) and [[Charles Wesley]] (1707–1788), founders of [[Methodism]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/christianity/subdivisions/methodist_1.shtml |title=Methodist Church |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref>
==Royalty== [[File:HM The Queen visit..jpg|thumb|Her Majesty, [[Queen Elizabeth II]]]] * [[Alfred the Great]] (848–899 A.D.).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/alfred_the_great.shtml |title=Alfred the Great (849 AD – 899 AD) |publisher=[[BBC History]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Richard I of England|Richard the Lionheart]] (1157–1199).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/richard_i_king.shtml |title=Richard I (1157–1199) |publisher=[[BBC History]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Henry V of England|King Henry V]] (1386–1422).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/henry_v_king.shtml |title=Henry V (c.1387 – 1422) |publisher=[[BBC History]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Richard III of England|King Richard III]] (1452–1485).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/people/king_richard_iii |title=King Richard III |publisher=[[BBC History]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Henry VIII of England|King Henry VIII]] (1491–1547).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/people/henry_viii |title=Henry VIII |publisher=[[BBC History]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Elizabeth I of England|Queen Elizabeth I]] (1533–1603).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Elizabeth-I |title=Elizabeth I |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Caroline of Brunswick]] (1768–1821), [[Princess of Wales]] 1795–1820; wife of [[George IV of the United Kingdom|George IV]] 1820–1821.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2011/aug/18/archive-caroline-of-brunswick-funeral-disorder-1821 |title=From the archive, 18 August 1821: Two killed in Queen's funeral procession |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Queen Victoria]] (1819–1901).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/timelines/ztn34j6 |title=Queen Victoria: The woman who redefined Britain's monarchy |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] (b. 1926).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://s.telegraph.co.uk/graphics/projects/queen-elizabeth-royal-style-icon/index.html |title=Queen Elizabeth II, style icon |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Diana, Princess of Wales]] (née [[Spencer family|Spencer]]; 1961–1997).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/01/princess-diana-martin-bashir-bbc-interview-video-photos-pictures-quotes_n_2192943.html |title=Princess Diana Martin Bashir Interview: The Most Memorable Moments From The Late Royal's BBC Sit Down |publisher=''[[The Huffington Post]]'' |accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref>
==Scientists== [[File:Sir Isaac Newton by Sir Godfrey Kneller, Bt.jpg|thumb|140px|Sir [[Isaac Newton]]]] * [[Francis Crick]] (1916–2004), co-discoverer (with [[James Watson]]) of the structure of the [[DNA]] molecule in 1953.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/northamptonshire/asop/people/francis_crick.shtml |title=Francis Crick 1916 – 2004 |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[John Dalton]] (1766–1844), best known for his pioneering work in the development of modern [[atomic theory]], and his research into [[Color blindness|colour blindness]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/3178890.stm |title=Science celebrates 'father of nanotech' |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Charles Darwin]] (1809–1882), best known for his contributions to [[evolution]]ary theory.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/timelines/zq8gcdm |title=Charles Darwin: Evolution and the story of our species |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Michael Faraday]] (1791–1867), discoveries include the principles underlying [[electromagnetic induction]], [[diamagnetism]], and [[electrolysis]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/faraday_michael.shtml |title=Michael Faraday (1791–1867) |publisher=[[BBC History]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Francis Galton]] (1822–1911), devised a method for classifying [[fingerprint]]s that advanced [[forensic science]]; initiated scientific [[meteorology]]; pioneered [[eugenics]], coining the phrase "[[nature versus nurture]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-13775520 |title=Francis Galton: The man who drew up the 'ugly map' of Britain |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Robert Hooke]] (1635–1703), [[Natural philosophy|natural philosopher]] and [[polymath]] of multiple innovations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/british/civil_war_revolution/hooke_robert_beavon_01.shtml |title=Robert Hooke, Natural Philosopher |publisher=[[BBC History]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Edward Jenner]] (1749–1823), said to have "saved more lives [...] than were lost in all the wars of mankind since the beginning of recorded history."<ref>{{Cite book |title=Edward Jenner, the Cheltenham years, 1795–1823|last=Saunders|first=Paul|year=1982|publisher=University Press of New England|isbn=978-0-87451-215-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Conqueror of smallpox: Dr. Edward Jenner|last=Levine|first=Israel E.|year=1960|publisher=Messner|isbn=978-0-671-63888-7}}</ref> * Sir [[Isaac Newton]] (1642-1727), widely recognised as one of the most influential scientists of all time and a key figure in the [[scientific revolution]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Isaac-Newton |title=Sir Isaac Newton: English physicist and mathematician |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref>
