web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2007/04/04/trumpton-voice-is-tvs-favourite-256638/ |title=Trumpton voice is TV's favourite |publisher=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> and ''[[Mr Benn]]'' (1971–2).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/3647513/Bowled-over-by-Mr-Benn.html |title=Bowled over by Mr Benn |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * ''[[The Wombles (1973 TV series)|The Wombles]]'' (BBC, 1973-5).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/562155/ |title=Wombles, The (1973–75, 1998–99) |publisher=[[Screenonline|BFI Screenonline]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref>
===Comedy=== * ''[[The Benny Hill Show]]'' (BBC/ITV, 1955–1991).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/7547472/Benny-Hill.html |title=Obituaries: Benny Hill |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Fawlty Towers]]'' (BBC, 1975-9).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7355383.stm |title=Towers tops online comedy survey |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Monty Python's Flying Circus]]'' (BBC, 1969–74).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2006/aug/02/heritage.politicsandthearts |title=The Ministry of Silly Icons |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * ''[[The Morecambe & Wise Show (1968 TV series)|The Morecambe & Wise Show]]'' (BBC, 1968–77; ITV, 1978–83).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/may/21/morecambe-wise-eddie-braben-dies |title=Morecambe and Wise writer Eddie Braben dies |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * ''[[On the Buses]]'' (ITV, 1969–73).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/8965930/After-40-years-On-The-Buses-is-still-right-upmy-street.html |title=After 40 years, On The Buses is still right up my street |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Some Mothers Do 'Ave 'Em]]'' (BBC, 1973-8).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/467706/index.html |title=Some Mothers Do 'Ave 'Em (1973–75, 1978) |publisher=[[Screenonline|BFI Screenonline]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref>
===Drama=== [[File:Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II Couronnement de la Reine Elizabeth II.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II]], broadcast [[Live television|live]] on 2 June 1953]] * ''[[Cathy Come Home]]'' and [[The Wednesday Play]] (1964–1970).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/438481/ |title=Cathy Come Home (1966) |publisher=[[Screenonline|BFI Screenonline]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/454700/ |title=Wednesday Play, The (1964–70) |publisher=[[Screenonline|BFI Screenonline]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Coronation Street]]'' (ITV, 1960–present).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/coronation-streets-sally-websters-top-7239134 |title=Coronation Street's Sally Webster's top moments in 30 years |publisher=[[Daily Mirror]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Dixon of Dock Green]]'' (BBC, 1955–76).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/473251/ |title=Dixon of Dock Green (1955–76) |publisher=[[Screenonline|BFI Screenonline]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Doctor Who]]'' (BBC, 1963–89; 1996; 2005–present).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/classic/episodeguide/index_third.shtml |title=Doctor Who: The Classic Series |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Play for Today]]'' (BBC, 1970–84).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/454719/ |title=Play for Today (1970–84) |publisher=[[Screenonline|BFI Screenonline]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Tales of the Unexpected (TV series)|Tales of the Unexpected]]'' (ITV, 1979–88).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/558532/ |title=Tales of the Unexpected (1979–88) |publisher=[[Screenonline|BFI Screenonline]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref>
===Other=== * ''[[Match of the Day]]'' (BBC, 1964–present). * ''[[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]]'' (1953–present).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/panorama/hi/front_page/newsid_7773000/7773981.stm |title=The Panorama decades |publisher=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II]] [[Live television|live broadcast]] (2 June 1953).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2013-06-02/why-elizabeth-iis-1953-coronation-is-the-day-that-changed-television |title=Why Elizabeth II's 1953 Coronation is the day that changed television |publisher=''[[Radio Times]]'' |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * ''[[The Sky at Night]]'' (BBC, 1957–present).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/1338648/index.html |title=Sky at Night, The (1957–) |publisher=[[Screenonline|BFI Screenonline]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Test Card F]] (BBC, 1967–99).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/technology/technology8.html |title=TV Technology 8. Britain In Colour – and UHF |publisher=[[Screenonline|BFI Screenonline]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * ''[[Top of the Pops]]'' (1964–2006).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/550139/index.html |title=Top of the Pops (1964–2006) |publisher=[[Screenonline|BFI Screenonline]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref>
==Transport==
===Cars=== [[File:Aston.db5.coupe (OA).PNG|thumb|200px|[[Aston Martin DB5]]]] * [[Aston Martin]], a manufacturer of [[Luxury vehicle|luxury]] [[sports car]]s and [[grand tourer]]s; associated since the 1960s with the fictional character [[James Bond]] following the use of a [[Aston Martin DB5|DB5]] model in the 1964 film ''[[Goldfinger (film)|Goldfinger]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/life/motoring/aston-martin-db5-named-the-most-iconic-british-car-of-all-time-28454422.html |title=Aston Martin DB5 named the most iconic British car of all time |publisher=''[[Belfast Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * The [[Ford Cortina]], built by [[Ford of Britain]] at [[Brentwood, Essex]] in various forms from 1962 to 1982.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2012/04/20/iconic-brand-new-ford-cortina-mk-v-up-for-sale-after-30-years-in-garage-395867/ |title=Iconic 'brand new' Ford Cortina MK V up for sale after 30 years in garage |publisher=''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * The [[Jaguar E-Type]], manufactured by [[Jaguar Cars]] between 1961 and 1975. * [[Land Rover]], a car brand that specialises in [[four-wheel-drive]] vehicles; the ''Land Rover'' name was originally used, from 1948, by the [[Rover Company]].<ref name=c24/> * The [[Mini]], made by the [[British Motor Corporation]] and its successors 1959–2000.<ref name=c24/> * [[Morris Minor]] (1948–1971), recognised as typifying "Englishness". * [[Rolls-Royce Limited]] and [[Rolls-Royce Motors]], renowned car-manufacturers 1906–1998; exemplified by the [[Rolls-Royce Silver Shadow]];<ref name=c24/> and the associated [[Bentley]] (1919–1998; bought by Rolls-Royce in 1931).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.autocar.co.uk/car-news/industry/history-bentley-picture-special |title=History of Bentley – picture special |publisher=''[[Autocar (magazine)|Autocar]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref>
===Water=== [[File:The stern of HMS Victory - geograph.org.uk - 865432.jpg|thumb|200px|[[HMS Victory]]]] * [[Cutty Sark]] (1869): a [[Clipper|tea clipper]] built by 19th century ship-owning firm [[Jock Willis Shipping Line|John Willis & Sons of London]]; in dry dock at [[Greenwich]], London since 1954.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/cutty-sark-2-ship-lovers-plan-seaworthy-replica-of-iconic-19th-century-vessel-a6743811.html |title=Cutty Sark 2: Ship-lovers plan seaworthy replica of iconic 19th-century vessel |publisher=''[[The Independent]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[HMS Dreadnought (1906)|HMS Dreadnought]] (1906): a [[Royal Navy]] [[battleship]] that revolutionised naval power.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-27641717 |title=How the Dreadnought sparked the 20th Century's first arms race |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * The [[Golden Hind]]: an English [[galleon]] best known for Sir [[Francis Drake]]'s [[circumnavigation]] of the globe between 1577 and 1580;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indrakeswake.co.uk/Artefacts/goldenhind.htm |title=Searching for Sir Francis Drake's Golden Hind at Deptford, London |publisher=In Drake's Wake |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> the ship does not survive, but a replica – the [[Golden Hinde (1973)|Golden Hinde]] (1973) – has been berthed at St Mary Overie Dock on Cathedral Street, in [[Bankside]], [[London Borough of Southwark|Southwark]] since 1996. * The [[Mary Rose]]: King [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]]'s [[warship]] sank on 19 July 1545 in the [[Solent]], the straits north of the [[Isle of Wight]]; the [[Shipwreck|wreck]] was rediscovered in 1971.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/museums/10088752/Life-and-death-on-the-Mary-Rose.html |title=Life and death on the Mary Rose |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * The [[Mayflower]]: the ship that transported the first English [[Separatism|Separatist]]s, known today as the [[Pilgrim Fathers|Pilgrims]], from [[Plymouth]] to the [[New World]] in 1620. * [[Narrowboat]]s: the original working boats built in the 18th, 19th, and 20th centuries for carrying goods on England's narrow [[canal]]s.<ref name=c24/> * [[HMS Victory]]: best known as [[Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson|Lord Nelson]]'s [[flagship]] at the [[Battle of Trafalgar]] in 1805; in [[dry dock]] at [[Portsmouth]] since 1922.<ref name=c24/>
===Air=== [[File:SpitI19a.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Supermarine Spitfire]]]] * The [[Avro Lancaster]] (1941–1963). * [[Concorde]] (1969–2003), jointly developed and manufactured by the [[British Aircraft Corporation]] and [[Aérospatiale]] under an Anglo-French treaty. * The [[de Havilland Comet]] (1949–1997), the first commercial [[jet airliner]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/9889220/A-Great-British-Air-Disaster-Channel-4-review.html |title=A Great British Air Disaster, Channel 4, review |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> and the [[Vickers VC10]] (1962–2013). * the [[Fairey Aviation Company]] (1915–1960). * The [[Hawker Siddeley Harrier]] (1969–2006). * The [[Sopwith Camel]] (1916–1920). * The [[Supermarine Spitfire]] (1936–1948) and the [[Hawker Hurricane]] (1935–1944).<ref name=c24/> [[File:Northern Routemaster.jpg|thumb|200px|[[AEC Routemaster]] bus]]
===Public transport=== * [[Blackpool tramway]], last surviving first-generation [[tram]]way in the United Kingdom.<ref name=c24a/> * British Railways, which from 1965 traded as [[British Rail]]; most nostalgically in the days of the [[steam locomotive]]. * [[Hackney carriage]] (also called a cab, black cab, hack or London taxi) * The [[London Underground]] or ''the Tube''; began operating in 1863. * [[AEC Routemaster]] bus (red London [[double-decker bus]]), entered service 1956.<ref name=c24/><ref name=PostalMuseum/> * [[The man on the Clapham omnibus]] became the expression used in English courts to symbolise a hypothetical ordinary and [[reasonable person]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/notesandqueries/query/0,,-2012,00.html |title=What is the origin of the expression 'The man on the Clapham omnibus'? |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref>
==Writers== [[File:Droeshout first state.jpg|thumb|200px|[[William Shakespeare]]]] * [[Middle English]] writers, notably: [[Geoffrey Chaucer]] (1343–1400),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bl.uk/collection-items/the-canterbury-tales-by-geoffrey-chaucer |title=The Canterbury Tales by Geoffrey Chaucer |publisher=[[British Library]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> and [[William Langland]] (c. 1332 – c. 1386).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/William-Langland |title=The Canterbury Tales by Geoffrey Chaucer |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Early modern period|Early modern]] dramatists, most notably: [[William Shakespeare]] (1564–1616).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bl.uk/press-releases/2015/september/british-literary-icons-to-be-exhibited-in-china-for-the-first-time |title=British literary icons to be exhibited in China for the first time |publisher=[[British Library]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Early modern period|Early modern]] poets, notably: [[John Donne]] (1572–1631),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/John-Donne |title=John Donne: English poet |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> and [[John Milton]] (1608–1674).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/John-Milton |title=John Milton: English poet |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Augustan literature|Augustan]] writers, notably: [[Alexander Pope]] (1688–1744),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Alexander-Pope-English-author |title=Alexander Pope: English author |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> and [[Samuel Johnson|Dr Johnson]] (1709–1784).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Samuel-Johnson |title=Samuel Johnson: English author |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Romantic poetry|Romantic]] poets, notably: [[William Wordsworth|Wordsworth]] (1770–1850),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/William-Wordsworth |title=William Wordsworth: English author |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> [[Samuel Taylor Coleridge|Coleridge]] (1772–1834),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Samuel-Taylor-Coleridge |title=Samuel Taylor Coleridge: British poet and critic |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> [[Lord Byron|Byron]] (1788–1824),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/George-Gordon-Byron-6th-Baron-Byron |title=George Gordon Byron, 6th Baron Byron: English poet |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> [[Percy Bysshe Shelley|Shelley]] (1792–1822),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Percy-Bysshe-Shelley |title=Percy Bysshe Shelley: English poet |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> and [[John Keats|Keats]] (1795–1821).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/John-Keats |title=John Keats: British poet |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Regency novel|Regency]] and [[Victorian literature|Victorian]] female novelists, notably: [[Jane Austen]] (1775–1817),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Jane-Austen |title=Jane Austen: English novelist |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> [[Charlotte Brontë]] (1816–1855),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Charlotte-Bronte |title=Charlotte Brontë: British author |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> [[Emily Brontë]] (1818–1848),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Emily-Bronte |title=Emily Brontë: British author |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> and [[George Eliot]] (1819–1880).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/George-Eliot |title=George Eliot: British author |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Victorian literature|Victorian]] novelists, most notably: [[Charles Dickens]] (1812–1870).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/c/charles-dickens-at-the-v-and-a/ |title=Charles Dickens at the V&A |publisher=[[Victoria and Albert Museum]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Victorian literature|Victorian]] poets, notably: [[Alfred, Lord Tennyson|Tennyson]] (1809–1892),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Alfred-Lord-Tennyson |title=Alfred, Lord Tennyson: English poet |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> and [[Robert Browning|Browning]] (1812–1889).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Robert-Browning |title=Robert Browning: British poet |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * Late 19th and early 20th century writers, notably: [[Thomas Hardy]] (1840–1928),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Thomas-Hardy |title=Thomas Hardy: British writer |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> [[Rudyard Kipling]] (1865–1936),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Rudyard-Kipling |title=Rudyard Kipling: British writer |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> and [[E. M. Forster]] (1879–1970).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/E-M-Forster |title=E.M. Forster: British writer |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * 20th century novelists, including: [[George Orwell]] (1903–1950),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/2011/06/orwell-vs-god/ |title=Orwell vs God |publisher=''[[The Spectator]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> [[Evelyn Waugh]] (1903–1966),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Evelyn-Waugh |title=Evelyn Waugh: English author |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> [[Virginia Woolf]] (1882–1941), and [[Graham Greene]] (1904–1991).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Graham-Greene |title=Graham Greene: British author |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * 20th century poets, including: [[John Betjeman|Betjeman]] (1906–1984),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/oxford/hi/people_and_places/history/newsid_8130000/8130664.stm |title=Sir John Betjeman in Oxfordshire and beyond |publisher=[[BBC Oxford]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> [[W. H. Auden|Auden]] (1907–1973),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/auden_wh.shtml |title=WH Auden (1907–1973) |publisher=[[BBC History]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> and [[Philip Larkin|Larkin]] (1922–1985).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-33148295 |title=Philip Larkin to get Poets' Corner memorial |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref>
==Miscellaneous== [[File:BedaleHunt2005.jpg|thumb|[[Fox hunting]], before the 2005 ban]] [[File:London telephone.jpg|thumb|[[Red telephone box]]es]] [[File:Changing of the Colours.jpg|thumb|[[Trooping the Colour]]]] [[File:The White Cliffs of Dover - geograph.org.uk - 106444.jpg|thumb|upright|The [[White Cliffs of Dover]]]]
* [[King Arthur]], central figure in the legends making up the so-called [[Matter of Britain]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/606196 |title=Reinventing an Iconic Arthurian Moment: The Sword in the Stone in Films and Television |publisher=[[Project MUSE]] |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Bank of England]], established 1694.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hand-picked.telegraph.co.uk/threadneedles-london/sale |title=Threadneedles Hotel |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Bayeux Tapestry]], final and best known work of [[Anglo-Saxon art]], made in England in the 1070s but held in a French museum.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/3650501/Plunging-horses-and-butchered-bodies.html |title=Plunging horses and butchered bodies |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Bettys and Taylors of Harrogate|Betty's Tea Room in Harrogate]], traditional tea rooms dating from 1919.<ref name=c24a/> * ''[[Blood Swept Lands and Seas of Red]]'' by [[Paul Cummins]], with setting by [[Tom Piper]]; an [[Installation art|installation]] at the [[Tower of London]] July–November 2014 commemorating the [[centenary of the outbreak of World War I]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/world-war-1/493048/WW1-commemoration-Tower-of-London-filled-with-poppies |title=Duke and Duchess of Cambridge join Prince Harry to plant poppies at the Tower of London |publisher=''[[Daily Express]]'' |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> * The neighbourhood "[[Law enforcement in the United Kingdom|bobby]]" on the [[Beat (police)|beat]], dating from the 19th century.<ref name=c24a/> * [[Boudica]] (d. A.D. 60 or 61), queen of the [[Celts|Celtic]] [[Iceni]] tribe who fought against the occupying forces of the [[Roman Empire]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.randomhouse.co.nz/books/vanessa-collingridge/boudica-9780091898205.aspx |title=Boudica |publisher=[[Random House]] |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Coldstream Guard]]s and [[Trooping the Colour]]. * English [[Eccentricity (behavior)|eccentricity]], some historical examples of which are documented in [[John Timbs]]' ''[[English Eccentrics and Eccentricities]]'' (1866).<ref name=c24/> * The [[English landscape garden|English garden]], a style of "[[Landscape architecture|landscape]]" garden which emerged in England in the early 18th century.<ref name=c24/> * [[Local government in England|English local government]], originating from the [[History of local government in England|municipal reform]] of the 19th century.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/place/United-Kingdom/Local-government |title=Local government |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[British humour|English sense of humour]].<ref name=c24/> * The [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|E.U. membership referendum]] of 23 June 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/feb/25/brexit-campaign-comedy-songs-eu-referendum |title=Already the Brexit campaign has comedy songs, ties and condoms. What's next? |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Fox hunting]], of 16th century origin; and the 2005 ban ([[Hunting Act 2004]]).<ref name=c24/> * [[Hedge]]s.<ref name=c24/> * [[Music hall]], a theatrical entertainment popular from the early [[Victorian era]] until 1960;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/page/m/music-hall/ |title=Music Hall & Variety Theatre |publisher=[[Victoria and Albert Museum]] |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> popularly revived on television by the [[BBC Television|BBC]]'s ''[[The Good Old Days (UK TV series)|The Good Old Days]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/788925/ |title=Good Old Days, The (1953–83) |publisher=[[Screenonline|BFI Screenonline]] |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Ordnance Survey]] maps; work commenced in 1791.<ref name=c24/> * [[Oxbridge]], a [[portmanteau]] word blending [[University of Oxford|Oxford University]] and [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge University]], used to refer to the two collectively in contrast to other universities.<ref name=c24/> * [[Pantomime]], a type of [[Musical theatre|musical comedy]] stage production for family entertainment, developed in England by "father of English pantomime" [[John Rich (producer)|John Rich]] (1692–1761).<ref name=c24/> * The [[Parish church]], the basic administrative unit of [[Episcopal polity|episcopal]] churches.<ref name=c24/> * The public house, or [[Pub]]. The great diarist [[Samuel Pepys]] (1603–1733) described the pub as the heart of England.<ref name=c24/> * [[Punch and Judy]], traditional, popular [[Puppetry|puppet]] show, associated with seaside [[Culture of the United Kingdom|culture]].<ref name=c24/><ref>{{cite news|title=Mr Punch celebrates 350 years of puppet anarchy|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-17895716|agency=BBC News|date=11 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=New icons of Englishness unveiled|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/4952920.stm|agency=BBC News|issue=27 April 2006|date=11 June 2015}}</ref> * The [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|Queen]]'s head on [[List of British postage stamps|postage stamp]]s.<ref name=c24/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/queens-head-on-stamps-guaranteed-by-law-2179981.html |title=Queen's head on stamps guaranteed by law |publisher=[[The Independent]] |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> See also: the [[Chalon head]]. * [[Queue area|Queuing]], the practice (once archetypally English) of waiting in line for one's turn to be attended to or to proceed.<ref name=c24/> * [[Pillar box|Red pillar box]]es (in use since 1852).<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/2294797.stm BBC article on English Heritage's preservation of them]</ref> * The [[Red telephone box]], dating from 1924.<ref name=c24/> * The [[Scouting|Scout movement]], created in 1907 by [[Robert Baden-Powell, 1st Baron Baden-Powell|Lord Baden-Powell]].<ref name=c24/> * The [[Seaside resort|seaside]] [[Pier|pleasure pier]], first built in England in the early 19th century.<ref name=c24/> * [[Stiff upper lip]], a display of [[Cardinal virtues|fortitude]] in the face of adversity, or an exercise of [[Self control|self-restraint]] in the expression of [[emotion]];<ref name=c24/> exemplified in [[Rudyard Kipling]]'s poem "[[If—]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/rudyard-kiplings-if-voted-nations-favourite-poem-1577258.html |title=Rudyard Kipling's 'If' voted nation's favourite poem |publisher=''[[The Independent]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * The [[Sutton Hoo helmet]], excavated in 1939 from a (c. 7th century) ship-burial and prompting comparisons with the world described in the heroic [[Old English]] poem ''[[Beowulf]]''.<ref name=c24/> * The London [[Tube Map]], designed originally in 1931 by [[Harry Beck]] (1902–1974).<ref name=c24/> * English [[Climate of the United Kingdom|weather]].<ref name=c24/> * The [[White Cliffs of Dover]]; of symbolic significance because they face [[Continental Europe]] across the narrowest part of the [[English Channel]], where invasions have historically threatened, and against which the cliffs form a symbolic guard; because crossing at Dover was the primary route to the continent before the advent of air travel, the white line of cliffs also formed the first or last sight of England for travellers.
==References== {{reflist|33em}}
==External links== * [http://postalheritage.org.uk/page/icons British Postal Museum & Archive: Icons of England] * [http://www.culture24.org.uk/art362437 Culture24: Icons of England] * [[List of cultural icons of the United Kingdom|List of Cultural Icons of the United Kingdom]]
{{England topics|state=uncollapsed}}

Documentaries - The Italian patient |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2008-10-10 |accessdate=2014-01-29}}</ref>

{{Infobox film | name = Lottovoittaja UKK Turhapuro | image = Lottovoittaja cover.jpg | caption = DVD cover. | director = [[Ere Kokkonen]] | writer = [[Spede Pasanen]] | starring = [[Vesa-Matti Loiri]],
[[Marjatta Raita]],
[[Tapio Hämäläinen]],
[[Marita Nordberg]],
[[Spede Pasanen]],
[[Seppo Laine]],
[[Simo Salminen]] | producer = [[Spede Pasanen]] | distributor = [[Funny-Films Oy]] | released = 1976 | runtime = 1h 24 min | country = [[Finland]] | language = [[Finnish language|Finnish]] }} '''''Lottovoittaja UKK Turhapuro''''' is a [[Finland|Finnish]] 1976 comedy film written by [[Spede Pasanen]] and directed by [[Ere Kokkonen]]. It is the third film in the [[Uuno Turhapuro]] series. The film's title translates to "Lottery winner UKK Turhapuro", UKK being an apparent reference to former President of Finland [[Urho Kekkonen]]. ==Plot== It is the first anniversary of Uuno ([[Vesa-Matti Loiri]]) and Elisabet ([[Marjatta Raita]]). Uuno has placed a bet with his friend Härski-Hartikainen ([[Spede Pasanen]]) a year ago, that if Uuno can take just one year of marriage with Elisabet, Hartikainen will treat him a festive dinner. However, Hartikainen buys a lottery ticket for Uuno, who agrees to deduct it from his debt – and the festive dinner is reduced to a can of milk and half a sausage. As it happens, Uuno becomes the lottery winner of 1.5 million [[Finnish mark|marks]], only to soon realize he doesn't own a single penny yet. Mister Tossavainen ([[Seppo Laine]]) arrives and offers to finance Uuno before he actually gets the jackpot. Thus, Uuno gets to live a rich live on credit. He buys a raccoon fur, leopard swimming trunks and a couple of [[Mercedes-Benz]]es. Women begin to fancy Uuno and so does his [[Councillor Tuura|father-in-law]] ([[Tapio Hämäläinen]]). As time goes by it is revealed, though, that Uuno is not actually a lottery winner, and so he has to escape the anger of others to Härski's car repair shop. ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0074818}} {{Uuno Turhapuro films}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lottovoittaja Ukk Turhapuro}} [[Category:Finnish films]] [[Category:1976 films]] [[Category:Spede Pasanen]] {{Finland-film-stub}} [[Category:Students]]

revision.text:
[[File:Монстрация 1 мая 2011 года, Новосибирск.jpg|thumb|Monstration signs are meant to be nonsensical, like "Raccoons are people too!"]]
A '''monstration''' is a public performance similar to a [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstration]], but intended as creative [[performance art]], often [[parody]]ing a serious demonstration. It is principally a [[Russia]]n phenomenon.<ref name=RT>{{cite news|title= Russian Labor Day: Rallies, ridicule and revelry as tens of thousands take part|url=http://rt.com/politics/labor-day-russia-politics-671/|accessdate=1 May 2013|newspaper=Russia Today|date=1 May 2013}}</ref>
==History==
=== Poland === [[Orange Alternative]] ([[Polish language|Polish]]: ''Pomarańczowa Alternatywa'') was a Polish [[anti-communist]] underground movement, started in [[Wrocław]], a city in south-west [[Poland]], in the 1980s.<ref>{{cite journal|date=March 1992|title=Between the State and Solidarity|journal=The British Journal of Sociology|volume=43|issue=1|pages=55–78|doi=10.2307/591201|author=Bronislaw Misztal}}</ref> Its main purpose was to offer a wider group of citizens an alternative way of opposition against the [[authoritarian]] regime by means of peaceful street protests that used absurd and nonsensical elements.
=== Russia === In 2004, [[Artyom Loskutov]] and members of the ''Contemporary Art Terrorism'' group in [[Novosibirsk]] joined the annual [[International Workers' Day|May Day demonstration]]. They were carrying posters with deliberately absurd slogans in an attempt to shake up a boring political procession and to make fun. Fellow [[Siberian]] artist Ivan Dyrkin named the march "Monstration," a [[Demonstration (acting)|demonstration]] without the prefix ''de,'' which he considered a negative connotation as in [[deconstruction]] or [[Biodegradation|degradation]].<ref name=TheSiberianTimes>{{cite news|last=Liesowska|first=Anna|title= The Siberian phenomenon of 'Monstrating'|url=http://siberiantimes.com/other/others/news/the-siberian-phenomenon-of-monstrating/|accessdate=1 May 2013|newspaper=The Siberian Times|date=1 May 2013}}</ref>
The modern monstration incorporates signs and messages that are deliberately absurd, nonsensical and apolitical that indirectly defy the government and express a conceptual [[paradox]]. Although monstrations are apolitical, participants have been arrested for [[political agitation]]. In 2010, Monstrations took place in 20 cities like [[Moscow]], [[Saint Petersburg]], and [[Vladivostok]].<ref name=France24>{{cite news||title= Russian youths invent absurd way to by-pass demonstration banurl=http://observers.france24.com/content/20110517-russian-youths-invent-absurd-way-pass-demonstration-ban|newspaper=France 24|date=17 May 2011}}</ref>
====Kursk==== The first monstration in [[Kursk]] took place on May 1, 2014. About 30 people with the main slogan "For the rights of butterflies in the stomach".<ref>[http://www.46tv.ru/new/society/002757/ 46tv.ru, В Курске прошла "Монстрация" (фото)]</ref>
<gallery> File:Za prava babochek v zhivote.JPG|"For the rights of butterflies in the stomach" File:Ulibni svoi ulibalnik.JPG|"Smile your smiler!" File:Na temnoi storone.JPG|"Rent a [[Death Star]]" and "Dark side has no cookies" File:Zhigulam litie diski.JPG|"[[Alloy wheel]]s to [[Zhiguli_(car_brand)|Zhiguli]]<ref>https://www.musixmatch.com/lyrics/%D0%9B%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4/%D0%9B%D1%8E%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%82-%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%88-%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4</ref>". </gallery>
In 2015, the main slogan was "We did not watch 50 Shades".
==Recognition== In 2011 Monstration was recognized for "Innovation" by a government agency of [[modern art]] and selected as "Best in the Region."<ref name=NewsRU>{{cite news|last=Liesowska|first=Anna|title= Русская служба BBC по требованию Роскомнадзора внесла правки в материал о "Марше за федерализацию Сибири"|url=http://www.newsru.com/russia/05aug2014/federalization.html|accessdate=5 August 2014|newspaper=News RU|date=5 August 2014}}</ref>
==Government outrage== In 2014, Artyom Loskutov attempted to organize a routine monstration for August 17, when he ran into trouble. “We were talking about having a march, which is absolutely allowed under law,” Loskutov says. “But in writing about it, we wrote about creating a [[Siberian Republic]] within the [[Russian Federation]]. There was no talk about [[separatism]] or anything, it’s just that Moscow doesn’t govern the regions very effectively.”<ref name=PRI>{{cite news|last=Maynes|first=Charles|title= As Snowden looks on, Russia cracks down on Internet freedom|url=http://www.pri.org/stories/2014-08-05/snowden-looks-russia-cracks-down-internet-freedom|accessdate=5 August 2014|newspaper=PRI|date=5 August 2014}}</ref>
The purpose of the protest was to ridicule Kremlin's hypocrisy in the [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation]] and to raise awareness about politics in Siberia. "They decided to tell us how great it is when some republic moves for [[self-determination]]. Okay, well let's apply this to other regions. Can Siberia allow itself this same rhetoric? It turns out it can't."<ref name=TheGuardian>{{cite news|last=Luhn|first=Alec|title= Russia bans Siberia independence march|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/05/russia-bans-siberia-independence-march-extremism-law|accessdate=5 August 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|date=5 August 2014}}</ref>
Russian telecommunications regulator [[Roskomnadzor]] launched a [[media blackout]] of the event, issued warnings to 14 media outlets that ran the story and threatened to close [[BBC Russian Service]] for reporting the announcement.<ref name=TheSiberianTimes>{{cite news|title= Authorities in Novosibirsk ban march to press for changing Siberia's status in Russia|url=http://siberiantimes.com/other/others/news/authorities-in-novosibirsk-ban-march-to-press-for-changing-siberias-status-in-russia/|accessdate=5 August 2014|newspaper=The Siberian Times|date=5 August 2014}}</ref> Roskomnadzor also launched an official investigation against BBC to confirm "an apparent violation of the law." In response, BBC added a description of the event as a “parody” that in no way promoted Siberia's independence from Moscow.<ref name=Itar-Tass>{{cite news|last=Rain|first=Andy|title= Russia to further examine provocative interview on BBC website|url=http://en.itar-tass.com/russia/743661|accessdate=5 August 2014|newspaper=Itar-Tass|date=5 August 2014}}</ref>
Russian authorities compared the potential monstration protest to [[Euromaidan]] that led to the [[2014 Ukrainian revolution]]. [[Nikolai Valuyev]] called it the "first attempt of global efforts to promote separatism in Russia."<ref name=BBC>{{cite news|title= Russia: Siberian autonomy web page shut down|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-news-from-elsewhere-28643523|accessdate=4 August 2014|newspaper=BBC News|date=4 August 2014}}</ref>
According to Dmitry Zhuravlyov, director of [[Russian Academy of Sciences#Institutions|Institute for Regional Problems]] based in Moscow, "I can understand the position of these people [organizers of the march] on a psychological level," Zhuravlyov said. "They want to have more control over the riches of Siberia, and that is understandable. But what is unacceptable to Russia is that this whole idea goes against the Constitution. You cannot change the status of your region just like that." President [[Vladimir Putin]] recently signed legislation that introduced prison sentences for violations of [[territorial integrity]] in Russia.<ref name=TheMoscowTimes>{{cite news|title= Blocked BBC Interview Highlights Authorities' Insecurities|url= http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/blocked-bbc-interview-highlights-authorities-insecurities/504637.html|accessdate=5 August 2014|newspaper=The Moscow Times|date=5 August 2014}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Internet censorship in Russia]] *[[Demonstration (acting)|Demonstration]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Monstration Monstration] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xeFS7fSy000 Monstration 2004-2008] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S98em4EdpAI Monstration 2012] [[Category:Pop-culture neologisms]] [[Category:Youth culture]] [[Category:Political controversies in Europe]] [[Category:Street theatre]]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Musical Interpretation Research''''' ('''MIR''') is a series of monographs on the performance of [[classical music]] authored by [[Nils-Göran Areskoug]] (Sundin). The focus is on integrating the perspectives of the audience, artist and musicologist alike. The series covers aesthetic experience in music appreciation with the aim of bridging theory and practice of interpretive processes among performer and conductor, by providing in-depth analyses of masterworks, elaborating a methodology for researching interpretative cognition and designing a set of criteria for excellence in music performance. The publications, originating in a project pioneering new music research in the Nordic countries at Uppsala University and Stockholm School of Music, were funded initially by grants from The Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and Torsten and Ragnar Söderberg Foundations jointly,<ref>[http://www.torstensoderbergsstiftelse.se/ Torsten Söderbergs Stiftelse]</ref> during 1979–1988.
The MIR series was first presented in 1983 at University of California San Diego, La Jolla (lecture in the C.A.R.L. series) and on invitation by Professor David Lewin at a visit to the Music Department, Harvard University; then premiered at a lecture-performance event in Stockholm, Sweden, on May 10, 1984, according to the press release issued by the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Music]].<ref>[http://www.muakad.se/ Kungliga Musikaliska Akademien (KMA)]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Subsequent research for the MIR series contains 'real world new music research', including dialogues with leading orchestra conductors (such as Sergiu Celibidache) and instrumentalists (pianists and violinists such as Hans Leygraf, Guido Agosti and Isaac Stern, respectively) along with studies of their rehearsal working processes.<ref>[https://sites.google.com/site/coleur/aremus Are Akademi]</ref>
== Editions == * ''Musical Interpretation in Performance'' - Excerpts from '''''Musical Interpretation Research''''', MIR Vols 1–2. Mirage edition (1983), Växjö, Sweden. 96 pages. ISSN 0349-988X, {{ISBN|91-86636-00-6}}. (''In English'') * ''Introduktion till Musikalisk Interpretation och Interpretationsforskning'' - ('''''Musical Interpretation Research''''', MIR volume 1). Mirage edition, Växjö, Sweden. 420 pages, 2nd edition (1984). ISSN 0349-988X, {{ISBN|91-86636-03-0}}. (''In Swedish'' with an Introduction in English) * ''Musikalisk interpretationsanalys'' - ('''''Musical Interpretation Research''''', MIR volume 2). Mirage edition, Växjö, Sweden. 453 pages, 2nd edition (1984). ISSN 0349-988X, {{ISBN|91-97040-31-2}}. (''In Swedish'' with a Synopsis in English)
== Related editions == * ''Musical interpretation in performance: Music theory, musicology and musical consciousness'', Journal of Musicological Research, 1984, Vol.5(1), p. 93-129, (Peer Reviewed Journal), ISSN 0141-1896 ; E-ISSN 1547-7304 ; DOI: 10.1080/01411898408574547 * ''Skapande interpretation och musikalisk instudering'', {{ISBN|91-970403-6-3}}, Stockholm : Mirage, 1983. (''In Swedish'') * ''Aesthetic criteria for musical interpretation - a study of the contemporary performance of Western notated instrumental music after 1750'', {{ISBN|951-34-0336-X}}, Jyväskylä : Univ. of Jyväskylä, 1994, 665 pages Series: Jyväskylä studies in the arts, ISSN 0075-4633; 45, Dissertation, PhD Thesis, Jyväskylä University, Finland. (''In English'')
== See also == * ''[[The Interpretation of Music]]''

revision.text:
A number of [[units of measurement]] were used in [[Oman]].
==System before metric system==
Several units were used.
===[[Muscat, Oman|Muscat]]===
====Length====
One covid was equal to 39.13 in.<ref name=":wmm53">{{Cite book|title = Weights Measures and Money of All Nations|last = Clarke|first = F.W.|publisher = D. Appleton & Company |year = 1891|location = New York|pages = 53}}</ref>
====Mass====
Units included:
1 [[maund]] = 24 kotschas = 8 3/4 lb
1 [[Candy (unit)|candy]] = 60 maunds.<ref name=":wmm53"/>
====Capacity====
One ferren was equal to 7.9254 gallons and also equal to 34 sidios.<ref name=":wmm53"/>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Systems of measurement}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} {{Infobox book| | name = Permutation City | title_orig = | translator = | image = PermutationCity(1stEd).jpg | caption = Cover of first edition (hardcover) | author = [[Greg Egan]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = Australia | language = English | series = | genre = [[Hard science fiction]], [[Postcyberpunk]] | publisher = Millennium [[Orion Publishing Group]] | release_date = 1994 | english_release_date = | media_type = Print (Hardcover and paperback) | pages = 310 | isbn = 1-85798-174-X | oclc= 30834713 | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = [http://www.gregegan.net/PERMUTATION/Permutation.html Official website] }} '''''Permutation City''''' is a 1994 science-fiction novel by [[Greg Egan]] that explores many concepts, including [[quantum ontology]], through various philosophical aspects of [[artificial life]] and [[simulated reality]]. Sections of the story were adapted from Egan's 1992 short story "Dust", which dealt with many of the same philosophical themes.<ref>[http://gregegan.customer.netspace.net.au/INTERVIEWS/Interviews.html#Aurealis Aurealis Interview (2009) by Russell Blackford].</ref> ''Permutation City'' won the [[Campbell award (best novel)|John W. Campbell Award]] for the best science-fiction novel of the year in 1995 and was nominated for the [[Philip K. Dick Award]] the same year. The novel was also cited in a 2003 ''[[Scientific American]]'' article on [[multiverses]] by [[Max Tegmark]].<ref>[[Max Tegmark]], [http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=parallel-universes Parallel Universes], ''[[Scientific American]]'', May 2003.</ref><ref>[[Max Tegmark]], [http://cosmos.phy.tufts.edu/~zirbel/ast21/sciam/ParalellUniverse.pdf Parallel Universes]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100620211331/http://cosmos.phy.tufts.edu/~zirbel/ast21/sciam/ParalellUniverse.pdf |date=20 June 2010 }}</ref>
==Themes and setting== ''Permutation City'' asks whether there is a difference between a computer [[simulation]] of a person and a "real" person. It focuses on a model of consciousness and reality, the ''Dust Theory'', similar to the [[Mathematical universe hypothesis|Ultimate Ensemble Mathematical Universe hypothesis]] proposed by [[Max Tegmark]]. It uses the assumption that human consciousness is [[Turing-computable]]: that consciousness can be produced by a computer program. The book deals with consequences of human consciousness being amenable to mathematical manipulation, as well as some consequences of simulated realities. In this way, Egan attempts to deconstruct notions of self, memory, and mortality, and of physical reality.
The '''Autoverse''' is an [[artificial life]] simulator based on a [[cellular automaton]] complex enough to represent the substratum of an [[artificial chemistry]]. It is deterministic, internally consistent and vaguely resembles real chemistry. Tiny environments, simulated in the Autoverse and filled with populations of a simple, designed lifeform, ''Autobacterium lamberti'', are maintained by a community of enthusiasts obsessed with getting ''A. lamberti'' to evolve, something the Autoverse chemistry seems to make extremely difficult.
Related explorations go on in [[Virtual reality|virtual realities]] (VR), which make extensive use of patchwork [[heuristic]]s to crudely simulate immersive and convincing physical environments, albeit at a maximal speed of seventeen times slower than "real" time, limited by the [[Optical computer|optical crystal computing]] technology used at the time of the story. Larger VR environments, covering a greater internal volume in greater detail, are cost-prohibitive even though VR worlds are computed selectively for inhabitants, reducing redundancy and extraneous objects and places to the minimal details required to provide a convincing experience to those inhabitants; for example, a mirror not being looked at would be reduced to a reflection value, with details being "filled in" as necessary if its owner were to turn their model-of-a-head towards it.
Within the story, "[[Mind uploading|Copies]]" – digital renderings of human brains with complete subjective consciousness, the technical descendants of ever more comprehensive medical simulations – live within VR environments after a process of "scanning". Copies are the only objects within VR environments that are simulated in full detail, everything else being produced with varying levels of generalisation, [[lossy compression]], and [[Hash function|hashing]] at all times.
Copies form the conceptual spine of the story, and much of the plot deals directly with the "lived" experience of Copies, most of whom are copies of wealthy billionaires suffering terminal illnesses or fatal accidents, who spend their existences in VR worlds of their creating, usually maintained by [[trust fund]]s, which independently own and operate large computing resources for their sakes, separated physically and economically from most of the rest of the world's computing power, which is privatized as a [[Fungibility|fungible]] [[commodity]]. Although the wealthiest copies face no financial difficulties, they can still be threatened because copies lack political and legal rights (they are considered software), especially where the global economy is in [[recession]]. Hence they cannot afford to retreat into solipsism and ignore what is happening in the real world.
At the opposite end from the wealthy Copies are those who can only afford to live in the virtual equivalent of "Slums", being bounced around the globe to the cheapest physical computing available at any given time in order to save money, while running at much slower speeds compared to the wealthy Copies. Their slowdown rate depends on how much computer power their meager assets can afford, as computer power is traded on a global exchange and goes to the highest bidder at any point in time. When they cannot afford to be "run" at all, they can be frozen as a "snapshot" until computer power is relatively affordable again. A Copy whose financial assets can only generate sufficient interest to run at a very slow rate is stuck in a rut because he/she/it becomes unemployable and is unable to generate new income, which may lead to a downward spiral.
By creating this scenario, Egan postulates a world where [[economic inequality]] can persist even in one's (virtual) afterlife.
The concept of [[solipsism]] is also examined prominently, with many less-wealthy Copies attending social functions called Slow Clubs, where socialising Copies agree to [[Synchronization|synchronise]] with the slowest person present. Many of these less-wealthy Copies become completely deracinated from their former lives and from world events, or else become ''Witnesses'', who spend their time observing (at considerable time lapse) world events unfold, at the cost of any meaningful relationships with their fellow Copies. A subculture of lower/middle-class Copies, calling themselves ''Solipsist Nation'' after a philosophical work by their nominal founder, choose to completely repudiate the "real" world and any Copies still attached to it, reprogramming their models-of-brains and their VR environments in order to design themselves into their own personal vision of [[paradise]], of whatever size and detail, disregarding slowdown in the process.
Egan's later novels ''[[Diaspora (novel)|Diaspora]]'' and ''[[Schild's Ladder]]'' deal with related issues from other perspectives.
==Story== The plot of Permutation City follows the lives of several people in a near future reality where the Earth is ravaged by the effects of climate change, the economy and culture are largely globalised, and civilisation has accumulated vast amounts of [[cloud computing]] power and memory which is distributed internationally and is traded in a [[Stock market|public market]] called the QIPS Exchange (Quadrillion Instructions Per Second, see [[Instructions per second|MIPS]]).
Most importantly, this great computing capacity has enabled the creation of Copies, whole [[Mind uploading|brain emulations]] of "scanned" humans which are detailed enough to allow for subjective conscious experience on the part of the emulation. Scanning has become safe enough and common enough to allow for a few wealthy or dedicated humans to afford to create backups of themselves. Copies do not yet possess human rights under the laws of any nation or international body.
===Part one=== In 2050, Paul Durham, a Sydney man having experimented on Copies of himself, offers wealthy Copies prime real estate in an advanced supercomputer which, according to his pitch, will never be shut down and never experience any slowdown whatsoever. Durham predicts that efforts to utilise [[Chaos theory|chaotic]] effects will clash with Copy rights, as both Copies and weather simulations will demand increasing QIPS Exchange shares. All that each Copy must do is to make the comparatively small investment of two million ecus in order to bring Durham's fantasy computer into existence.
Durham hires Maria Deluca, an Autoverse enthusiast, to design an Autoverse program which, given a powerful enough computer, could generate a planet's worth of evolvable Autoverse life. He also clandestinely commissions a famous virtual reality architect, Malcolm Carter, to build a full scale VR city; outside of Durham's knowledge, Carter secretly hacks two Slum-dwelling Solipsist Nation Copies (Peer and Kate) into this city's [[machine code]]. When Maria learns of a [[computer fraud]] investigation on Durham, she confronts him.
Durham reveals that his self-experiments convinced him that there is no difference, even in principle, between physics and mathematics, and that all mathematically possible structures exist, among them our physics and therefore our spacetime, a belief he refers to as "Dust Theory". The dust theory implies that all possible universes exist and are equally real, emerging spontaneously from their own mathematical self-consistency. Because Copies exist in virtual realities held together by heuristics merely for the sake of their experience, it should be the case that when a Copy is terminated and deleted, its own conscious experience will continue. Indeed, Durham himself claims to have been through such a process dozens of times.
Durham uses the money from his financial backing to simulate a minute or two of a "[[Garden of Eden (cellular automaton)|Garden of Eden]]" configuration of an infinitely-expanding, massively complex cellular automaton universe, in which each iteration of the expansion serves to "manufacture" an extra layer of blocks of a computing configuration.<ref>This is similar to what is known as a "Spacefiller" configuration in [[Conway's Game of Life]]) based on a fictional, [[Turing-complete]] cellular automaton and referred to as a TVC ("''Turing/Von Neumann/Chiang''"), named after its conceiver and designer.</ref> According to his Dust Theory, such a simulation would create a self-consistent "TVC universe" to persist in its own terms even after its termination and deletion. His and his investors' Copies [[Closure (computer science)|would therefore persist]] indefinitely in the simulation. The Autoverse planetary seed program designed by Maria is included in the TVC universe package for his investors to explore once life had evolved there after it had been run on a significantly large segment of the TVC universe (referred to as "Planet Lambert").
After a successful launch, simulation, termination, and deletion of the TVC universe, Durham and Maria have uncomfortable sex in awkward celebration, and later that night, while Maria is asleep, Durham disembowels himself with a kitchen knife in his bathtub, believing his role as the springboard for his deleted TVC Copy to discover its true identity to be fulfilled.
===Part two=== Maria wakes in Permutation City seven thousand years of subjective time after the launch, furious at Durham for awakening her. He explains to her that intelligent life has arisen on Planet Lambert in the form of complex swarms of insect-like eusocial beings, evolved from Maria's original ''Autobacterium hydrophilus''. He wishes to use Maria's slice of the universe's processing power (as a founder of the world she was given de facto control of a continuously-growing zone of the processor network as well) to make forbidden first contact with Lambertians. He believes this is necessary because he has lost the ability to pause the Autoverse simulation or slow it down past a constant multiple of the size of the processor network it occupies. Durham is worried that the rules of their simulated universe are breaking down.
They discover that the combined intelligence of Lambertians has exceeded that of Permutation City; as such, the TVC universe is being overwritten into a system existing solely as a byproduct of the self-perpetuation of the Autoverse. Durham, Maria, and some other companions quickly launch an emergency expedition into the Autoverse to attempt to convince the Lambertians of the validity of the creator hypothesis and its methodological perferentiality over their own newly formulated theory. Unfortunately, the Lambertians reject the creator theory, prompting Permutation City and the entirety of TVC processor-networks to begin collapsing into nothing. Durham and Maria inform the inhabitants of Permutation City, who launch a new TVC Garden of Eden in their universe's final moments. Maria convinces a reluctant Durham to come along to a new universe, pledging to work with her to discover the underlying rules that governed the Autoverse's takeover of Permutation City.
==See also== {{portal|Novels}} * [[Artificial consciousness]] * [[Event symmetry#Greg Egan.27s dust theory|Event symmetry]] * [[Hidden surface determination]] * [[Mind uploading]] ** [[Mind uploading in fiction]] ** ''[[The Age of Em]]''

==Further reading== *{{citation |last=Farnell |first=Ross |year=2000 |title=Attempting Immortality: AI, A-Life, and the Posthuman in Greg Egan's 'Permutation City' |journal=Science Fiction Studies |volume=27 |issue=1 |pages=69–91 }}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.gregegan.net/PERMUTATION/Permutation.html}} * [http://www.gregegan.net/PERMUTATION/FAQ/FAQ.html The Dust Theory: FAQ]
